channel.title: ItemDefinitions
channel.description:
I was working on storks server a bit to try and get a base completed to finally get rid of all Winterlove servers I was dumping data that i would need for the server and I wanted to make sure I got everything.
[code]<ItemDefinition> <name>Ammo mould</name> // Not really needed but wouldn't be bad for the server to know. <id>4</id> // item id <members>true</members> // do i really have to say <stackable>false</stackable> // ditto <isNote>false</isNote> // this can be used for any transactions. <value>5</value> // this value is saved client side i know some math functions are done to it to get different values, not really sure if this is what jagex uses for selling to shops and what not, but I know it gets its Default price value for item drop array sorting <equipId>-1</equipId> // this has to be set manually for the server to know if its lets say a Hat <bonus> // I counted 12 normal bonuses, However I'm really not sure what you would do for lets say special items like Boots of lightness that decreased you weight, This is not a normal bonus. <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> </bonus> </ItemDefinition>[/code]
if I'm missing any important values please let me know.

[/quote]
thought the god was semaphore.[/quote]
Well, Sean is a god, and Semawhore is a god to.

THEY’RE BOTH FUCKING GODS!

item.title: ItemDefinitions
item.dc:creator: @Sean Sean
item.description:
@Sean wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:17, topic:213176”][quote author=Miss Silabsoft link=topic=280650.msg2300961#msg2300961 date=1214607633]

Xstream was never meant to be used in the ways stork abused it, for the love of god, stop storing all of this info in xml

what would you suggest?
[/quote]
he wont be posting again

just use sql or some binary formatted file[/quote]

Oh wont I, frankio. I wasnt going to actually post untill you said that. Idk, ive always bitched that I want to see people innovating, doing things their way… Whats the point if I just sit here and tell you how to do everything, all of the fun is in design. Just because some code did something one way, doesnt mean its the right way, theres alot of rscd I regretted in the end, infact, before I quit I had announced an entire rewrite coming (tho I had announced I was pulling out the xml loading code before this).

Read full topic

item.title: ItemDefinitions
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

sql is just as easy imho. Wonderful thing about interfaces is you can load the data how ever you want.

XStream provides alternative implementations of java.io.ObjectInputStream and java.io.ObjectOutputStream, allowing streams of objects to be serialized or deserialized from XML.

This is useful when processing large sets of objects, as only one needs to be in memory at a time.

seems like this would be useful for definition files.

Read full topic

item.title: ItemDefinitions
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:2, topic:213176”]WOW CODE TAGS OMG

Just a quick note, the members here would not get how to “work” XML, even if it is this simple.

Anyways, cant you modify the shop’s “examine” option for items serverside? Maybe even just the general examine option as well. Dont remember too clearly, but if my memory serves me right, then the shop examine option would work.[/quote]
Here is that problem solved

A quick xstream load on start, xstream save on quit

Read full topic

item.title: ItemDefinitions
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

For things such as boots of lightness, you could use a field, itemWeight, and assign it a negative value.
Anyway, I can’t think of anything left out off the top of my head.

Read full topic

item.title: ItemDefinitions
item.dc:creator: @silabsoft RuneAgent
item.description:
@silabsoft wrote:

xstream is really not that difficult… I think even a moparscaper can figure it out, It involves no koding the way rscd was setup, just add the alias, and add the reading of the file with the presistancemanager I mean shit if its that complicated make a frame that loads the xml file on startup have it be a table, and make it save it on close.

Read full topic

item.title: ItemDefinitions
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:4, topic:213176”][quote author=Thug-life link=topic=280650.msg2282077#msg2282077 date=1213746259]

WOW CODE TAGS OMG

Just a quick note, the members here would not get how to “work” XML, even if it is this simple.

Anyways, cant you modify the shop’s “examine” option for items serverside? Maybe even just the general examine option as well. Dont remember too clearly, but if my memory serves me right, then the shop examine option would work.

They could work with xml, if its forced upon them.
[/quote]When winterLove servers were forced upon them, did THAT work too?[/quote]
Winterlove Servers were never forced on them, they only used them because it was the only public server available.

Read full topic

<ItemDefinition> <name>Ammo mould</name> // Not really needed but wouldn't be bad for the server to know. <id>4</id> // item id <members>true</members> // do i really have to say <stackable>false</stackable> // ditto <isNote>false</isNote> // this can be used for any transactions. <value>5</value> // this value is saved client side i know some math functions are done to it to get different values, not really sure if this is what jagex uses for selling to shops and what not, but I know it gets its Default price value for item drop array sorting <equipId>-1</equipId> // this has to be set manually for the server to know if its lets say a Hat <bonus> // I counted 12 normal bonuses, However I'm really not sure what you would do for lets say special items like Boots of lightness that decreased you weight, This is not a normal bonus. <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> <int>0</int> </bonus> </ItemDefinition>
